ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I guess learn how to solve basic econ problems.
I've learned a lot about microeconomics, and feel like I better understand why decisions are made.
This course gave me a solid QR base for understanding intro Microeconomics. Additionally, I learned necessary microeconomic theories and their practical applications.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is really bad. It's only strength is the small class size. The teacher uses a terrible text book, that he doesn't follow. The text book uses it's own set of formulas, and the teacher says not to use them, and provides a different set of formulas, thus making the textbook almost completely useless. The teacher explains problems terribly, thus putting the student in a tough position, because they don't understand how to solve problems like the textbook or the teacher. I would also say, this course is too math heavy. It's intro economics, I still have no idea how the market works! Instead of trying to understand the market through math concepts, why don't we just focus on economic theory's and gain a strong understanding of them. Also, there are only 4 homework assignments. These are long problem sets, however, you can get a max of 10 points on each problem set. Thus, these problem sets to very little for your grade, putting heavy emphasis on the midterm and final. I think this class would be much better if it had smaller problem sets worth more points, thus promoting a better understand of the subject. Several smaller tests focused on specific concepts we learned in class would also be more beneficial.

Tolga was great. He definitely seems to care about us, and was more than willing to further explain things and go over things again when asked. He was also giving out seemingly good life advise throughout the class, based on what he was talking about that day.
i liked how straight forward it was, very clear

The material for this course can be dense and challenging, but a strength of this course is that Professor Koker breaks it down in a way that is approachable. Having access to recorded lectures (both from the current semester and past recorded lectures), was immensely helpful because it allowed me to take more time with difficult concepts. Professor Koker also included links to supplementary materials that were really useful for studying. Overall, Professor Koker's experience and organization of this class was its greatest strength. I can't think of an area of the course that I found particularly weak.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked how the classes were recorded. I had to miss a few (doctors, power outage), and being able to watch them later, or just rewatch class when I realized I missed something in my notes was really nice.
Professor Koker was great at interacting with his students and made learning this somewhat straightforward topic entertaining and fun.
it translated pretty nicely, tolga was already familiar with online teaching so it worked well

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No! The Professor is terrible. The class structure is bad. He's a nice guy, but can't teach for his life. I never want to take an Econ class again because how bad this experience was.

This is a great class! It might not cover topics that advanced, but what do you expect from a class with "foundations" in the name? As someone who knew next to nothing about economics going in, I think I learned a lot. The workload wasn't that bad either, and Tolga was great.
Yes, it provides a deep understanding of the microeconomics through a close setting.
yes, but it is a lot of learning by yourself as the course is very fast paced.

I would definitely recommend this course. I typically struggle with QR topics, and though I still found this class to be quite challenging, Professor Koker was supportive and able to present the information in a way that was less intimidating.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There is also recorded lectures available to the student.
Class was recorded and later uploaded, and a recorded lecture from a previous year was also available.
